“Do you Blog” as an interview question

Posted by stevehebert on July 22, 2004

I’m looking at refining my interview pieces as our company moves ahead and the question that keeps popping in my head is whether “Do you blog” is useful in feeling out a programmer’s desire.


Disclaimer:  By placing this question on a blog, I risk asking the choir what they think. However I think the question is valid and merits discussion.


Ideally a question has a yes/no right/wrong answer for the sake of HR, but in an interview we are also trying to get a sense of fitness for the job.  I believe that every great programmer I’ve worked with has something to share with the software community – and they know it.  Some call it arrogance, some call it confidence, but ultimately a programmer desires to (1) make something unique and innovative and (2) have their code run on as many machines as possible. Without confidence a programmer won’t test the limits of the technology available and look around for new ways to solve problems.  A programmer who fails to desire these traits resorts to being a simple coder/scripter.  If an interviewee said “I have a blog”, I would read it top to bottom and I’m sure it would reveal materials that reach far beyond the scope of the 1 hour technical interview.


Back in the 90′s I used the “have you read Code Complete” question as a springboard into a lot of insight and discussion.  I think that “Do you Blog” has the potential to bring out a lot of the same insight.  Does this person desire to turn out the best code possible? Does the programmer look to others in developing their own skill?  Does the programmer contribute effectively with other developers? 


What do you think?

4 Responses to “Do you Blog” as an interview question

  1. laurence timms says:
    July 22, 2004 at 9:35 am

    I know several very good developers who don’t ‘blog’ and may never do so. As Richard says, asking "in which communities do you participate" is much more likely to elucidate useful information. Don’t forget that those communities may include human to human interaction. You know, *talking*.

    Also, I would still ask ‘Have you read Code Complete’.

  2. Richard Dudley says:
    July 22, 2004 at 8:37 am

    I would prefer to be asked someting more along the lines of "In what communities do you participate?" I could mention DNJ, ASP.NET, PGH DNUG, etc. Not to mention I’ve been participating in BBSs since about 1983. This probably isn’t a great answer for HR to handle, since it opens discussion that may be obove their capabilities. If the interviewer have been online, we could reminisce about the old GT-BBS and 2400 baud, PC Pursuit, TradeWars, and the transformation to forums and blogs. The interviewer would be able to obtain good insight into not just my comfort with on-line, but also my sense of community, as well as the knowledge I share and gain from being in the communities. I’d prefer the interviewer for this question be either technical or someone who has been in similar communities.

    My blog is only a couple of months old, but I have picked up two freelance contracts because of postings on another forum.

  3. Andrew Whitten says:
    July 22, 2004 at 6:06 am

    I regard myself as a very novice ‘blogger’, and in fact wouldn’t like to think that the content of my blog reflects my professional life.

    That said, I am aware prospective employers could look at my blog in the future, so I contain no personal or political items, as well as any information sensitive to my current employer.

    I’d be interested to know if anyone has been offered an interview, based solely on an employer finding their blog and finding it interesting?

  4. Tim Weaver says:
    July 22, 2004 at 5:24 am

    "Ideally a question has a yes/no right/wrong answer for the sake of HR"

    Not really sure I agree with this statement. Sure there are a lot of questions that are black and white, but then there are a lot of questions that aren’t about right/wrong, but about how the interview subject tackles the problem; e.g. you give the candidate a technically challanging problem to solve. Are you interested in the technology used (well yes, but only in so much that it isn’t blatently the wrong choice) what you really want to understand is how the person approaches complex problems.

    The question Do You Blog (and Code Complete as well) in my opinion are also targeted towards how you tackle a problem.

    I agree it is a good point of reference to learn about the candidate. I’ll be asking it next time I interview someone.
